title: Steven + Amethyst
description: Inspired by Steven Universe! I was poking around the sprites library (because of commuting I end up working in the offline editor a lot) and found a purple helicopter, which reminded me of Amethyst as a helicopter. I coded the project while riding the subway, with the purple helicopter and Gobo as sprite stand-ins, and then swapped sprites and added music when I got somewhere with wifi. I had also tried to reuse my newly learned gravity from previous Getting Unstuck days, but those really only worked with button presses, as opposed to "forever gravity" blocks. And since Steven only needs to float once...it was fine.
instructions: Press the green flag to watch. Move the mouse onto the helicopter to annoy Amethyst, and leave her alone for some praise.

title: Fussy Cat Simulator
description:
I was super inspired by @Mittensbrother's "Easily Spooked" project from Day 8 (https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/236238057/) and wanted to do something similar with an easily-annoyed-cat theme. :)

I like the discovery aspect of the project. Two things I'm still thinking about:
(1) Do I have bugs? The logic of my program seemed straightforward in theory:
   cat is initially fussy
   if you leave it alone for long enough, it is not fussy
   if it is not fussy, you can pet it
   if you pet it for too long, it gets fussy again
But the implementation seem convoluted. I need a code review. :)
(2) Is it too much discovery? (Will the temptation to peek into the code be really high? :))
instructions: Sparkles the Cat, who runs the notorious Time Laboratory, has demanded that her beleaguered assistant, Jeff, pet her. But Sparkles is a bit fussy. Jeff has reached out to you for help. Can you help Jeff figure out how to pet Sparkles the Cat without getting clawed?

title: Affection
description:
This was such a fun project to make! I'm really enjoying continuing to work with the vector editor! 

At first I had the curled-up cat and close-up cat within the same sprite (as many costumes). In order to make use of the "next costume" block, I decided to separate them out to separate sprites. 
Working on fixing a bug that causes the two to overlap during some of the transitions.
instructions: After pressing the green flag, press the space bar and use the mouse to interact with the cat.

title: Secret
description: This project was created for Day 13 of Getting Unstuck. I really enjoyed today's challenge to think about what happens when the mouse is moved further or closer from a location. But I definitely had to play with a few different project concepts before I found something that I liked.
instructions: Press the green flag and try to find the secret spot by moving your mouse around. If you can click the exact spot, the secret will be revealed.

title: Unstuck Day 13
description: I tried to leverage some of the requisites of creativity for this assignment, mainly limitation: I used a simple sprite and little code, and I allowed myself about 10 minutes to make the project while getting ready to go to work. I also lost track of the precise instructions (regarding a mouse getting close to a sprite), and didn't let this concern me too much in what I was making. I just worked with mouse and sprite. To be creative also means I'll return to this with some ideas that occur later in the day or overnight, so I'm marking it as a draft. Everything is a draft.
instructions: Green flag, click the mouse on stage and move it around

title: Unstuck Day 13: React to Mouse
description:
I made this project in response to the prompt for Challenge #13-respond to mouse- of the Getting Unstuck initiative from the ScratchEd Team:
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu
I couldn't make the sprite and its clones respond after a few seconds of not touching them because that blocks the interactivity, but i did manage to get them to behave differently depending on whether the wand (lightning) was touching them or they were away from the mouse. I learned that while clones cannot keep their own instance of a variable they do have their own position and can be aware of how far they are from the mouse pointer.
instructions:
Cook the magic stew! Use your magic wand to make the stew boil but work quickly, if you stop using your wand the ingredients will shrink.

Update: Thanks @jsh for clueing me to the fact that clones can keep their own variables if a varialbe is create "only for this sprite." Now each clone is maintaining its own effect amount and waiting its own amount if it is neglected by the mouse before it starts shrinking.

title: Bored Electron
description:
Getting Unstuck - day 13
by Massimo Marletta

In this project I used the block "distance from mouse pointer" to calculate the Coulomb repulsion force between two electrons (which is proportional to the inverse of the distance between them).
The timer is user to sequence the events (i.e. electron waiting, electron bored, etc.)
I had a lot of fun drawing costumes for the electron sprite with my children.
instructions:
In this project we have a bored electron: yes, a poor negative charge all alone in the void space.
The mouse pointer is another electron and you can apply Coulomb force to the bored electron simply getting close to him. 
Put a bit of fun in his boring life!
But be attentive to him: if you stay too long without pushing the electron he will complain because your are not paying enough attention to him!

title: Happy Birthday, Mom!

I thought about giving him sounds as he walks or thinks, but they weren't necessary and I removed them. Dog2 is quiet sophistication personified.

title: Getting Unstuck: Day 13 — Reactive Color
description:
Reflection

I wanted something that would react to mouse gestures and ended up with lots of dots that cycle through the hue when a mouse gets within a certain distance. The dots continue to cycle for a time even after the mouse is out of range. Eventually, the hue for each dot will cycle back to red.

There's definitely room for improvement here. For example, I would like to spend time working on a process for creating a better random distribution than the default "go to random" block.
instructions: Move the mouse pointer.

title: Getting Unstuck #13
description:
I'm quite pleased with this. If I had a bit more energy I'd try to make sure the lion wasn't moving quite so much. Also, the munching sound goes on for too long when the lion stops eating. The only way to fix this, I think, is to make the sound loop shorter, which I didn't want to do because then it gets far too repetitive. I might try to fix it by adding a few different short recordings and playing them in sequence. Maybe that will mean that they can be interrupted more easily.

Thanks to @welfringer for fixing my audio problem. 

Another thing that I've noticed from doing this and my Howard Arkley project on Day 9 is that my appreciation for the artworks increases with my exposure to them. Although I don't feel great about stealing the artworks, I'm sure that it has been good for me.

I'm losing all sense of positive digital citizenship and just stealing images. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sleeping_Gypsy
https://thegaudyblog.wordpress.com/2013/05/02/on-rewatching-monty-python-and-mocking-the-french/
instructions: Press the green flag. Move your mouse near the lion to stop the gypsy from being eaten. If your mouse stops moving for too long an old friend pops in to visit.

Well I got a bit off track, I realize as I'm finishing this. I didn't have time to have the sprite change as the mouse pointer gets closer. It took a long time to figure out how to check position, for closeness and getting closer/farther. I'm happy with what I learned.
To improve the program, I would like to have an "indicator sprite" in the corner showing the "level of closeness," maybe a gauge that gets fuller with closeness? I think my code is well structured to add that in.
instructions: Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

title: Taco Dog
description:
I stumbled a bit on the clone replication with this one, as I wanted to delete tacos that were eaten and then pop up a new one after a delay. Because "delete this clone" must be at the end of a sequence, I tried several apporaches to initializing a new clone one second after the previous was removed, each with surprisingly different results:

- Send and recieve broadcast: This was my first attempt, and it served the purpose of not creating a clone until after the delay. It also, however, created a new clone for each of the existing clones on the screen (as each was receiving the broadcast separately, I assume). This made for a kind of fun version where you need to eat tacos quickly to avoid a taco explosion, but not quite what I was looking for.
- Function: My second attempt was to create and call a function that waited and then cloned. The "wait" inside my function blocked execution in the loop from which it was called (execution blocking commands are tricky!), so it didn't behave any differently than if I had just called the wait and clone inline.
- Hide: This is the one I ended up going for - just hide the clone I plan on deleting right away so it doesn't really matter that it doesn't get deleted until after the clone is created.

Other approaches could include using a timer or a non blocking alternative to wait (like the mod of a counter var), but I'm gonna leave well enough alone :)
instructions: Use the mouse to get the dog to eat those tacos!

In this project, I draw different costumes, tinkered with time, sound, and rhythms to create the crab's movements and expressions.
Thanks to @Augusto, after seeing his project, I wanted to use his idea and includied another sprite following the crab, the crab's shadow.

title: Challenge 13 - ants don't like that!
description:
Had to think of something quickly, under 30 minutes, and threw together a group of ants that like their space. Make them angry and run with the mouse. 

The program uses a list to track all the distances to each ant. However, each ant clone will always know its distance from the mouse pointer so the list isn't necessary however it makes debugging a lot easier when you can see their data. Quick fun project
instructions:
Had to keep it very simple today for lack of time due to work, BOOO! My 4.5 hours on number 12 yesterday put me behind. So quick one today. But still fun nevertheless

But the ants do not like to be near the mouse and will get angry and scurry away until they are far enough to be comfortable.

title: Creepy Chaser -- Unstuck Challenge 13
description:
I'd still like to make my cloned bugs crawl around randomly on the screen until approached by the mouse.  I couldn't quite come up with a scheme I was happy with yet.  For now it's OK.  I still don't quite have the hang of the clone command.  I'd like them to all flash and move out of sync, but I will need to look into how to make that happen later.  Maybe they each need to be their own sprite.

In one iteration, the code had both the original sprite and the clones making clones.  That was quite fun as the screen quickly filled up!

title: Tag: Getting Unstuck Day 13
description:
Getting Unstuck Day 13

The idea of interacting with the mouse led me to the idea of tag. I don't know if my project really fulfills the brief, but I enjoyed making it.
If I were to continue working on it, I would introduce a few other elements, such as making the reaction of "running away" sprites dependent on their distance to "it." 
In addition, I would have the characters call out "You're it!" or "I'm it!" when they were tagged.
instructions: Press the green flag. Play tag as Scratch Cat.

title: Ant them - Getting Unstuck day 13
description:
uThe difficult part was to do not think too big. I wandered a lot of time on internet looking for spritesheet to use in the project as I do not have time and skill to create a sprite by myself.

I Started with a dragon guarding a threasure, the passed on a cat playing with the mouse pointer (did anyone remember neko on X?)

I do not achieve to get an usable spritesheet, diminished again the size of the project and decided to animate an ant nest. 

Unlike the real ones, the ant populations will cap at 30 individuals.
instructions:
Ants are usually shy but odds are that you can foster a community of curious individuals, did you manage to attain such a result?

As the ants approach your mouse they react in different ways depending on their character. Most of them are shy and will return to the nest. Some are just curious and if you leave they resume wandering. Some others will chase your mouse and you will have to find a way to get rid of them. Yes, you can peruse into the code.

title: Will the cat catch the parrot?
instructions:
When you move the mouse pointer left and right the parrot will follow it. If you stay more than 3 seconds without moving the mouse pointer then the cat will ask to move the mouse pointer (the parrot).
Whren the parrot is closer to the cat it will jump. If the cat gets in contact with the parrot the game is finished.

title: No Te Gusta Moz? (Unstuck 13)
description:
I just saw Antman and the Wasp and a scene from it inspired today's response to the prompt. This was the first time I've tinkered with this approach and it's definitely given me some ideas on how to apply it in other ways, especially with student projects. 

(Also, I'm out of town for the next few days, so these next projects might be a little rough until I can polish them up.)

The whole Getting Unstuck process has been a quite a gift - there's still so much to learn, but now I have a new sense of creative confidence going into each day. Thank you!
instructions: Press the flag to start. Keeping the mouse away makes Morrissey sad. But then again, so does keeping it close.

title: generative art - shy interactive barcodes
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 13
https://gettingunstuck.gse.harvard.edu/
Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

This project evolved organically, with many intermediary versions discarded while pursuing interesting glitches. The result could definitely be rewritten cleaner and more efficiently with the pen blocks, but I like the analog feel of the current iteration using stamps :)

ToFix: When using the full screen height 180x2, the line sometimes gets stuck on the bottom of the screen - why it is not moving further?

ToDo: Play with interactive colors, line thickness, speed... anf get back to a more "barcodes" look!
instructions:
Move the mouse closer/further away from the middle axis to help shape this computer-generated drawing.

Press space to pause and admire your work of art :)

title: Spaceship survivor
description:
Inspired by classical spaceship arcade game I've created a simple shooting game.
The ship moves faster or slowly depending on the distance from the enemy. I decided to added this kind of movement to make the game more challenging.

                                         ---My next goal---
I'd like to add more enemies, safe zones when you can hide and maybe some power-ups.

                                            ----Credits----
+ Sprites and backgrounds: All of them have been created with the Scratch paint editor.
instructions:
Press the play button to start.
Use the mouse to move your ship.
When you see "target" on the screen you could shoot your enemy by pressing the space bar.
Try to get as many points as possible. 
**Tips**: don't forget to get "HP" before it dissappears.

                                  ---Getting Unstuck day 13---
"Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently".

title: Unstuck Day 13: Hide and Seek
description: This is my second attempt at Challenge 13. Tried coding using strategies of @mauretta @clarimer @alirb.  Had trouble getting mine to work.  Computer has been glitchy last few days. (Too many lines of code? Too many sprites?)  When sprites were reduced in size, they seemed to move better.  Also layers seem to be important. If more than one sprite, does the mouse interact with only the top layer?  Not sure if the mouse is controlling motion here . . . Giga seems to move even when mouse not nearby, and seems to get stuck near the rock, which is two layers below. Tips and advice would be appreciated if you have suggestions :)
instructions: Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently.

title: Ode to Joy
description:
Getting Unstuck: Day 13 
Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently. 

Reflection - The screen is a bit crowded and Fred the worm could do with an upgrade. Not exactly to the brief but I had fun with it.         



"Ode to Joy" (German: "An die Freude" [an diː ˈfʁɔʏdə]), is an ode written in the summer of 1785 by German poet, playwright, and historian Friedrich Schiller and published the following year in Thalia. A slightly revised version appeared in 1808, changing two lines of the first and omitting the last stanza.

"Ode to Joy" is best known for its use by Ludwig van Beethoven in the final (fourth) movement of his Ninth Symphony, completed in 1824. Beethoven's text is not based entirely on Schiller's poem and introduces a few new sections. His tune[1] (but not Schiller's words) was adopted as the Anthem of Europe by the Council of Europe in 1972 and subsequently by the European Union.
Reference - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ode_to_Joy\

I was inspired by cooljewels piano keys project view:
https://scratch.mit.edu/projects/115556287/#player
There you will find the notes to simple tunes.
instructions: Click the green flag to start. Move your mouse point to Beethoven to begin. Follow the worms body as you pass over the notes and play the tune. Have fun!

title: Steven The Bug
description:
Ok, I've been spending waaay too much time on this, but I'm super proud of my project today.

I've always been wanting to make a sprite that follows the mouse with their eyes, so this project seemed to be a good opportunity to do it. Then I realized how cool it would be to feature Steven, inspired by project made today by @Mittensproject, @augusto and @aitan

After playing a bit with the imported image, it was clear to me that Steven deserved a vector version. I started playing with the graphic editor and I got stuck there! My strategy today was "keep going" and that made me to spend hours to create Steven, my first vector sprite ever! I was so excited and proud that I couldn't stop, so I also made vector graphics for the scratch blocks, inspired by the awesome illustrations made by the Getting Unstuck team.

Feel free to use Steven and the script blocks in your projects, you can also add new costumes or improve them!

Happy debugging!
instructions:
Steven The Bug doesn't like to be caught.
Move the mouse slowly and see what happens when you get closer.
Press space bar to generate a new background.

title: Fussy Cat Simulator remix
description:
I, the cat, make the rules (or, do I?) 
The hand may pet me at any time
I will react differently to the hand depending upon certain conditions
I am fussy when the hand first meets me
When I get fussy, I hiss
To avoid being hissed at, the hand must be a certain distance away from me for a count from 0 to 20
When I am happy, I purr
I purr softly to let the hand know that it may approach me
I purr loudly when the hand is petting me after a break, but only for a short while  
I get fussy again each time after a countdown from 20 to 0
I am actually controlled by the hand
I am an A.I. cat!!!!

I do not naturally excel at writing or following logic. I persevered to analyze and understand @karenb 's code. Scratch is hard to read when there are multi-layered nests of code. After using post-it notes on my kitchen counter, I decided to use some "my blocks" and comments in my remix.
instructions: Sparkles the Cat, who runs the notorious Time Laboratory, has demanded that her beleaguered assistant, Jeff, pet her. But Sparkles is a bit fussy. Jeff has reached out to you for help. Can you help Jeff figure out how to pet Sparkles the Cat without getting clawed?

title: Getting Unstuck Day 13 - reaction
description:
When I saw the instructions for this challenge I immediately pictured a ball moving around almost like a magnet being repelled. I had no idea how to do that until I saw @mcshicks project and was able to remix it. I'm still not sure exactly how the script works, but I was able to modify it enough to realize my vision.

I still wish I could figure out how to make it move smoother (so the lines were not staggered - maybe similar to the Bored Electron project)

title: Getting Unstuck - Day 13
description:
The challenge for day 13 is, "Create a sprite that reacts whenever the mouse pointer gets too close. If you leave the sprite alone for a few seconds, it should react differently." 

Scratch the cat will ask someone to chase him if the dog is not moving toward him.  Once the dog starts to move towards Scratch, he will begin to move away.

I used the Scratch Wiki to figure out how to make the dog follow the mouse pointer.  This project also made me think about layering.  I started by just trying to program everything at once... Then I figured out that I should start with just the cat and making it move, then program the dog to follow, then program the speaking.

I would definitely like to clean it up a little bit and make it flow more smoother.
instructions:
Click the green arrow to get started.

Use the mouse/touchpad to control the dog.

title: Getting Unstuck- Day 13
description: Using a if-else block and the distance variable, I made the vampire move away from the mouse. If I had more time, I would make the monster glide away from the mouse while simaltaneously crying for help. Such is the dichotomy with vampires--very brutal but even the most innocent garlic can conjure thoughts of horror!
instructions: Try to touch the monster using the mouse...Can they be defeated?
